summary: Jose Miro Cardona was a prominent figure in the Cuban exile community and a key player in anti-Castro activities. He is mentioned in several FBI and CIA documents related to the Cuban Revolutionary Council and efforts to overthrow Fidel Castro's regime. Cardona's potential resignation from the Cuban Revolutionary Council due to perceived changes in U.S. policy towards Cuba is noted, indicating his leadership role and influence within the exile movement. He was also involved in communications with Guatemalan officials, specifically Carlos Alejos, regarding anti-Castro activities, suggesting his coordination with other nations in the effort to remove Castro from power. The documents highlight his involvement in the broader context of Cuban exile activities, including potential training bases and attempts to gain support from other countries like Panama.
significance: While the documents do not directly link Jose Miro Cardona to the JFK assassination, they place him within the network of anti-Castro Cuban exiles, some of whom have been theorized to be involved in the assassination. His leadership role in the Cuban Revolutionary Council and his involvement in anti-Castro activities make him a person of interest in understanding the broader context of the political climate and potential motivations of various actors related to Cuba during that period.
